moves.1. e4 e5 2. f4 exf4 3. Nf3 g5 4. h4 g4 5: The Rice Gambit. All games in this mini-tournament start from this position. It may not be a sound gambit by Grandmaster standards -- you won't see Anand break it out playing against Kramnik -- but one thing can be said for sure: it does lead to interesting play.
moves.8... Bxe5 9. Re1 g3 10. Rxe5+: This game was one in which momentum shifted back and forth with almost every move. I momentarily equalize the material...
moves.10... Be6 11. dxe6: ...only to blunder away the Exchange with this move...
moves.11... Qd4+: ...after my opponent comes up with this nice bit of tactical play.
moves.12. Kh1 Qxe5 13. exf7+: I ended up getting a Pawn for the Exchange, and a threatening one at that. My position isn't great but it's playable.
moves.13... Ke7 14. Nc3: Time to start developing the Q-side.
moves.14... Nc6 15. d3 h5 16. Bd2 Ng4: With a Knight, a Queen and two advanced Pawns pointing at my King's position, my opponent has something going here. Time to focus on defense for me.
moves.17. Qe1: Momentarily freezing the Black Q to the K-file. With 17... QxQ 18 RxQ ch K-B3 Black could have entered an end game one Pawn up, but he understandably thinks he can still attack my King which is isolated in the corner.
moves.17... a6 18. Qxe5+: I decide to remove the threat by exchanging Queens.
moves.18... Ncxe5 19. Re1 Rh7 20. Bxf4: Material is even again and with 20...K-B3 Black could have preserved the balance, with a good chance of an eventual draw. The Knight would be unpinned and would threaten to capture my advanced Pawn.
moves.20... Kd6: A mistake. With the Knight still pinned, now by the Bishop, I can attack and win it with my QP.
moves.21. d4 b5 22. Bb3 c5 23. dxe5+: Not only winning the Knight, but if 23... K-B2 threatening 24 P-K6 dis ch with two connected, advanced passed Pawns.
moves.23... Kc6: This, however, is worse. Now I can win the Rook on QR1 with a skewer.
moves.24. Bd5+ Kc7 25. Bxa8 Rxf7: Black's position looks hopeless, but now it's my turn to blunder. I simply overlook 26... RxB.
moves.26. e6+ Rxf4 27. e7 Nf6 28. Nd5+: The decisive blow. Now the Knight either must move or be captured, allowing my Pawn to promote.
moves.28... Nxd5 29. e8=Q Rxh4+ 30. Kg1: I still have to be slightly careful. With my King stuck on KN1, a back-rank mate possibility exists.
moves.30... Nf4 31. Qe7+ Kc8 32. Qxh4: With the Rook -- and back-rank mate chance -- gone, Black resigns.
